content.raw:
I checked that the file is properly logged up to the point when the world is destroyed. I guess that's the expected behaviour, right? I tried this:

1. Start `gzserver` recording a log of a world with movement:

    `gzserver -r --record_path ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/ ../worlds/random_velocity.world --verbose `

2. Give it some time to record something

3. Open a new world that has moving stuff:

    `./pub_open_world ~/gazebo_source/gazebo/worlds/underwater.world`

4. Give it some time so we know the other world has been loaded and there are things moving and all. 

5. Then close `gzserver`.

6. Now playback the file and check we logged the first world:

    `gazebo --verbose -p ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/state.log -u`
content.html:
I checked that the file is properly logged up to the point when the world is destroyed. I guess that's the expected behaviour, right? I tried this:

  1. Start gzserver recording a log of a world with movement:

    gzserver -r --record_path ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/ ../worlds/random_velocity.world --verbose

  2. Give it some time to record something

  3. Open a new world that has moving stuff:

    ./pub_open_world ~/gazebo_source/gazebo/worlds/underwater.world

  4. Give it some time so we know the other world has been loaded and there are things moving and all.

  5. Then close gzserver.

  6. Now playback the file and check we logged the first world:

    gazebo --verbose -p ~/logs/open_world_random_velocity/state.log -u
